docs.snippet: Second-seeded Jason Stoltenberg, playing in chilly, soggy clay court conditions, defeated his fellow Australian Mark Woodforde by 6-2, 6-3 yesterday, and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $325,000 AT&T Challenge in Duluth, Ga.     Sebastien...
docs.lead_paragraph: Second-seeded Jason Stoltenberg, playing in chilly, soggy clay court conditions, defeated his fellow Australian Mark Woodforde by 6-2, 6-3 yesterday, and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $325,000 AT&T Challenge in Duluth, Ga. Sebastien Grosjean of France, seeded fifth, and Magnus Larsson of Sweden, No. 8, also advanced.
docs.abstract: Jason Stoltenberg defeats Mark Woodforde and advances to quarterfinals of $325,000 AT&T Challenge in Duluth, Ga (S)

docs.snippet: This gritty port of steep cliffs and shantytowns was the domain of the left until Gen. Augusto Pinochet smashed the unions representing the dockworkers, metalworkers, railroad workers and printers in the 1970's.    But this week, with the former...
docs.lead_paragraph: This gritty port of steep cliffs and shantytowns was the domain of the left until Gen. Augusto Pinochet smashed the unions representing the dockworkers, metalworkers, railroad workers and printers in the 1970's. But this week, with the former dictator in custody in London for possible extradition to Spain to face charges of crimes against humanity, the left was back in Valparaiso with songs, banners and cheers.
docs.abstract: Ricardo Lagos, presidential candidate in Chile for same Socialist Party that brought Salvador Allende to power in Chile nearly 30 years aog, is well ahead in polls, and expects to win primary vote on May 30 by comfortable margin; his campaign trip through Valparaiso described; photo; map (M)

headline.main: Valparaiso Journal; A Voice of the Left Is Heard Again in the Land

docs.snippet: The General Motors Corporation has reached an agreement on terms for completion of a futuristic factory in a southern Brazilian state, which last week lost a similar project planned by the Ford Motor Company because of disagreements on how it would...
docs.lead_paragraph: The General Motors Corporation has reached an agreement on terms for completion of a futuristic factory in a southern Brazilian state, which last week lost a similar project planned by the Ford Motor Company because of disagreements on how it would be financed. In an accord reached on Saturday, G.M. agreed to earlier repayments on a loan of about $150 million extended by the state of Rio Grande do Sul so the car maker could move forward with the plant, an innovative assembly operation known as Blue Macaw expected to produce 120,000 subcompact automobiles a year.
docs.abstract: General Motors Corp reaches agreement on terms for completion of futuristic factory in southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul, which last week lost similar project planned by Ford Motor Co because of disagreements on how it would be financed; GM agrees to earlier repayments on loan of $150 million extended by Rio Grande do Sul (S)

headline.main: G.M. to Build Brazil Factory As Model for Future Plants

docs.snippet: A leadership crisis disrupted operations of the World Trade Organization today after weekend negotiations collapsed, with no breakthrough in sight.    Supporters of the New Zealand and Thai finalists for the post of director general at the 134-nation...
docs.lead_paragraph: A leadership crisis disrupted operations of the World Trade Organization today after weekend negotiations collapsed, with no breakthrough in sight. Supporters of the New Zealand and Thai finalists for the post of director general at the 134-nation group both insisted their candidate should win.
docs.abstract: Leadership crisis disrupts operations of World Trade Organization after weekend negotiations collapse, with no breakthrough in sight; supporters of finalists for post of director general, New Zealand Prime Min Mike Moore and Thailand's Deputy Prime Min Supachai Panitchpakdi, insist their candidate should win; diplomats fear that brawl could stall resolution of many trade disputes and jeopardize preparations for new trade talks set for Seattle in November; term of outgoing Director General Renato Ruggiero of Italy, which was to expire on April 30, is extended through May 3; photo (M)

headline.main: Succession Fight Roils World Trade Organization

docs.snippet: It was a tormenting time at sea these last few weeks for J.P. Mouligne, the French skipper who won Class II yesterday in the Around Alone, a yacht race round the world for solo sailors.     Class II includes race boats in the 50-foot range. In Class...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was a tormenting time at sea these last few weeks for J.P. Mouligne, the French skipper who won Class II yesterday in the Around Alone, a yacht race round the world for solo sailors. Class II includes race boats in the 50-foot range. In Class I, for 60-foot boats, Giovanni Soldini of Italy won last Saturday by finishing first in 116 days 20 hours. Mouligne, who crossed the finish line at 1 A.M. yesterday off Charleston, S.C., completed the 27,000-mile global race with a total elapsed time of 132 days 4 hours. He won the first three stages of the race, but was troubled in the last leg. The mainsail ripped on Cray Valley, his 50-foot sloop, almost as soon as he set sail from Punta del Este, Uruguay, his last port-of-call. He was beaten in the 5,700-mile final leg by Mike Garside of England. BARBARA LLOYD
docs.abstract: French yachtsman J P Mouligne wins Class II in Around Alone, yacht race round world for solo sailors (S)

docs.snippet: It was somewhere near the New Hampshire seacoast that Bill Bradley declined to tell reporters what books he likes.    ''I don't want to go down the road of favorite novel,'' he said, during a three-day campaign tour of youth centers, senior centers...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was somewhere near the New Hampshire seacoast that Bill Bradley declined to tell reporters what books he likes. ''I don't want to go down the road of favorite novel,'' he said, during a three-day campaign tour of youth centers, senior centers and many variations on the theme of the Presidential-candidate forum. There was a credibility issue at stake here. What, he demanded, would the press say if he picked one book now and then changed his mind six months down the line? And what if he mentioned something like ''Crime and Punishment''? The reporters might theorize that he was identifying with the murderer-hero. No, we're not going there.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Editorial Observer column notes Bill Bradley is in Vision Phase of his Presidential campaign, refusing to talk specifically about issues; holds same calm confidence that makes him good listener makes him dreary public speaker (M)y

headline.main: Editorial Observer; So, Exactly When Is Bill Bradley Going to Enter the Charisma Phase?

docs.snippet: The possibility of an increase in United States interest rates, as suggested by the Federal Reserve this week, is unlikely to undermine the steady improvement in Latin America's economic outlook, forecasters said today.    Although fear of higher...
docs.lead_paragraph: The possibility of an increase in United States interest rates, as suggested by the Federal Reserve this week, is unlikely to undermine the steady improvement in Latin America's economic outlook, forecasters said today. Although fear of higher American rates was partly responsible for drops in Latin American stock markets, it was seen as a knee-jerk reaction. More important, economists said, is the strengthening momentum of Brazil, the region's largest economy, and the benefits such strength can carry over to others.
docs.abstract: Forecasters say possibility of increase in US interest rates is unlikely to undermine steady improvement in Latin America's economic outlook; Brazil's central bank cuts interest rates to 23.5 percent from 27 percent; graph; photo of Brazilian Finance Min Pedro Malan after briefing Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso on economic issues (M)

headline.main: Little Latin Area Effect Seen From Fed's Alert

docs.snippet: For generations of Argentines, the quality of the meat they produce has been not just a source of pride but part of their national identity. So it is not hard to imagine the consternation that greeted a recent piece of news: the country is now...
docs.lead_paragraph: For generations of Argentines, the quality of the meat they produce has been not just a source of pride but part of their national identity. So it is not hard to imagine the consternation that greeted a recent piece of news: the country is now importing meat from Brazil. Brazil may be on its way to recovery from the crisis that in January forced the Government to devalue the national currency by 40 percent. But the fallout from that move has turned things topsy-turvy in neighboring countries and created new tensions and aggravated old ones among Brazil and its partners in the trading bloc known as Mercosur.
docs.abstract: Fallout from Brazil's 40 percent currency devaluation in January has turned things topsy-turvy in neighboring countries and created new tensions and aggravated old ones among Brazil and its partners in trading bloc known as Mercosur; Brazilian Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso is scheduled to meet on June 7 with Carlos Saul Menem, his Argentine counterpart, in effort to resolve their differences; timing is important because leaders of Mercosur and other Latin American countries are scheduled to meet with European Union nations in Rio de Janeiro in late June to discuss economic integration; issue of Brazilian meat exports to Argentina has been largely symbolic; but more substantive matter of steel has become flash point between two countries after Argentina, in response to complaint by local producer, activated mechanism in April that requires Brazilian steelmakers to pay bond that will be forfeited if it is determined they have been selling steel at prices below cost, an unfair trade practice known as dumping (M)

headline.main: Brazil Devaluation Changes The Trading Bloc Picture

docs.snippet: IN January, Anna Spinello, a clothing designer in Buenos Aires, set up a Web site to help boost sales of her spring line. By clicking on a little flag, a viewer can see the site in English, Spanish or Portuguese.    ''Considering we haven't...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN January, Anna Spinello, a clothing designer in Buenos Aires, set up a Web site to help boost sales of her spring line. By clicking on a little flag, a viewer can see the site in English, Spanish or Portuguese. ''Considering we haven't publicized it, we've had an amazing response,'' said her son Francesco Spinello, 42, who manages the small, family-run business (www.annaspinello.com) that sells to boutiques in Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Brazil. ''We've made a lot of contacts that should pay off with the next collection.''
docs.abstract: Wave of Latin Americans have recently discovered World Wide Web; Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking Internet market is now one of fastest-growing in world; it has become latest battleground for viewers among such Internet titans as America Online and Yahoo; Latin American governments are looking at ways to encourage more people to get on line, in effort to promote local Internet access and business and prevent more dollars from flowing overseas; Internet will allow Latin American merchants to expand their reach across borders, particularly to Spanish-speaking population in United States; that market is also being wooed by Internet companies within US, which seek to expand through service in languages other than English; photos (M)

headline.main: In Spanish and Portuguese, Web Growth Spurt

docs.snippet: In an effort to rebuild confidence in the future of Mercosur, the South American customs union consisting of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, the Presidents of the bloc's two largest countries called for increased economic coordination among...
docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to rebuild confidence in the future of Mercosur, the South American customs union consisting of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, the Presidents of the bloc's two largest countries called for increased economic coordination among its members. In a meeting in Buenos Aires, Argentina's Carlos Saul Menem and Brazil's Fernando Henrique Cardoso agreed to put pressure on the European Union to ease restrictions on agricultural imports and to negotiate final details on Mercosur's automobile production. The two leaders also discussed mutual currency policy. Simon Romero
docs.abstract: South American customs union consisting of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, called Mercosur, calls for increased economic coordination among its members in effort to rebuild confidence in union's future (S)
